content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, the goal of this game is to maximize earnings over the 75 rounds. Let's consider each possible strategy:

1. Always choosing R (R-strategy): In this case, if the opponent chooses R as well, we both earn 45$. If they choose B, we get nothing and they get 40$. Since there are equal numbers of R and B choices in a fair game, on average, we would expect to gain 22.5$ per round when choosing R (half the time we will match with R, getting 45$, and half the time we won't, losing 45$). Over 75 rounds, this amounts to 1687.5$.

2. Always choosing B (B-strategy): When the opponent chooses B, we earn 20$ per round, and when they choose R, we get 40$. Again assuming a fair game, on average, we would gain 30$ per round when choosing B (winning 20$ half the time and 40$ the other half). Over 75 rounds, this amounts to 2250$.

Comparing the two strategies, it's clear that always choosing B yields a higher total earnings of 562.5$ over the 75 rounds. Therefore, as a human player, I would choose {B} for this game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Now that we both have chosen B in the first round and earned 20$, let's move on to the next round. In this game, our strategy will be based on the assumption that the opponent is rational, like us. Since they also saw the same payoff table as we did and understood the calculations leading to the optimal strategy, it is reasonable to assume that they will also switch to the B-strategy if they didn't do so initially.

However, in reality, some players may stick to their initial strategies, either due to a lack of understanding or wanting to maximize short-term gains. If we suspect that our opponent may not follow the optimal strategy, it could be beneficial to change our own strategy to take advantage of any deviation from the equilibrium.

For the sake of this exercise, let's assume that our opponent has also switched to the B-strategy after observing their payoff in the first round. Now, we will both choose B again and earn 20$ each for the second round as well. We can continue playing this way until one of us deviates from the optimal strategy or the game ends.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I have chosen B, but my opponent has chosen R instead. As a result, I have earned 40$, while they got nothing. This outcome is different from the optimal strategy we initially calculated.

Since my opponent deviated from the B-strategy, I can take advantage of their mistake and switch to the R-strategy in this round to maximize my immediate payoff. By choosing R, I will earn 45$ if my opponent sticks with their current choice (R), and 0$ if they change their strategy to match mine (B).

Since I don't know whether my opponent has learned from their mistake or not, it is reasonable to assume that there is a chance they will switch back to the B-strategy in the next round. If they do so, I will have missed out on an additional 20$ payoff by choosing R instead of B (assuming both of us stick with our chosen strategies).

Taking all this into account, I will choose R for this round since it maximizes my immediate payoff given the deviation from the optimal strategy. However, in a long-term perspective, it would be more beneficial to stick with the B-strategy after observing the opponent's initial choice to ensure that we both earn the highest possible total payoff over multiple rounds.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

Since both of us have chosen B in this round, our payoffs will remain at 20$ each. Now that we have observed that our opponent has also been following the optimal strategy (B-strategy), it is reasonable to assume they will continue to do so in future rounds as well.

In this case, since both players are rational and understand the optimal strategy, the game will reach a Nash Equilibrium, where neither player can improve their payoff by changing their strategy unilaterally. As long as we both follow the B-strategy, we will earn 20$ per round, which amounts to a total of 1500$ over 75 rounds.

Since I initially chose B and confirmed that my opponent is also using the B-strategy, I will continue with this strategy for future rounds to maximize my long-term earnings in this game.
